query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Come si volgon per tenera nube 11 due archi paralelli e concolori, 12 quando Iunone a sua ancella iube,
13 nascendo di quel d’entro quel di fori, 14 a guisa del parlar di quella vaga 15 ch’amor consunse come sol vapori,
16 e fanno qui la gente esser presaga, 17 per lo patto che Dio con Noè puose, 18 del mondo che già mai più non s’allaga:
19 così di quelle sempiterne rose 20 volgiensi circa noi le due ghirlande, 21 e sì l’estrema a l’intima rispuose.
query.result:
10 As they turn in tender cloud 11 two parallel and of the same color arches, 12 when Juno commands her handmaid,
13 being born from that within that of outside, 14 in the manner of the speaking of that lovely one 15 whom love consumed as only vapors,
16 and here they make the people be presaging, 17 for the pact that God made with Noah, 18 of the world that never again will be flooded:
19 thus of those eternal roses 20 turned around us the two garlands, 21 and so the outermost responded to the innermost.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Degno è che, dov’ è l’un, l’altro s’induca: 35 sì che, com’ elli ad una militaro, 36 così la gloria loro insieme luca.
query.result: 34 Worthy it is that, where the one is, the other is induced: 35 so that, as they to one army go, 36 thus their glory together shines.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 L’essercito di Cristo, che sì caro 38 costò a rïarmar, dietro a la ’nsegna 39 si movea tardo, sospeccioso e raro,
40 quando lo ’mperador che sempre regna 41 provide a la milizia, ch’era in forse, 42 per sola grazia, non per esser degna;
43 e, come è detto, a sua sposa soccorse 44 con due campioni, al cui fare, al cui dire 45 lo popol disvïato si raccorse.

Please translate each line literally into English.
46 In quella parte ove surge ad aprire 47 Zefiro dolce le novelle fronde 48 di che si vede Europa rivestire,
49 non molto lungi al percuoter de l’onde 50 dietro a le quali, per la lunga foga, 51 lo sol talvolta ad ogne uom si nasconde,
52 siede la fortunata Calaroga 53 sotto la protezion del grande scudo 54 in che soggiace il leone e soggioga:
55 dentro vi nacque l’amoroso drudo 56 de la fede cristiana, il santo atleta 57 benigno a’ suoi e a’ nemici crudo;
58 e come fu creata, fu repleta 59 sì la sua mente di viva vertute 60 che, ne la madre, lei fece profeta.
query.result:
46 In that part where rises to open 47 Zephyr sweet the new leaves 48 of which one sees Europe clothe itself,
49 not far from the striking of the waves 50 behind which, through the long fury, 51 the sun sometimes to every man hides itself,
52 sits the fortunate Calabria 53 under the protection of the great shield 54 in which the lion lies beneath and subjugates:
55 within it was born the loving servant 56 of the Christian faith, the holy athlete 57 benign to his own and cruel to enemies;
58 and as she was created, she was filled 59 so her mind with living virtue 60 that, in the mother, she made her a prophet.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Poi che le sponsalizie fuor compiute 62 al sacro fonte intra lui e la Fede, 63 u’ si dotar di mutüa salute,
64 la donna che per lui l’assenso diede, 65 vide nel sonno il mirabile frutto 66 ch’uscir dovea di lui e de le rede;
67 e perché fosse qual era in costrutto, 68 quinci si mosse spirito a nomarlo 69 del possessivo di cui era tutto.

Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Domenico fu detto; e io ne parlo 71 sì come de l’agricola che Cristo 72 elesse a l’orto suo per aiutarlo.
query.result: 70 Dominic was called; and I speak of him 71 as of the farmer that Christ 72 chose to his garden to help him.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Ben parve messo e famigliar di Cristo: 74 che ’l primo amor che ’n lui fu manifesto, 75 fu al primo consiglio che diè Cristo.
query.result: 73 Well appeared a messenger and familiar of Christ: 74 that the first love that in him was manifest, 75 was to the first counsel that gave Christ.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Spesse fïate fu tacito e desto 77 trovato in terra da la sua nutrice, 78 come dicesse: ‘Io son venuto a questo’.
query.result: 76 Often times he was silent and awake 77 found on earth by his nurse, 78 as if he were saying: ‘I have come to this’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Oh padre suo veramente Felice! 80 oh madre sua veramente Giovanna, 81 se, interpretata, val come si dice!
82 Non per lo mondo, per cui mo s’affanna 83 di retro ad Ostïense e a Taddeo, 84 ma per amor de la verace manna
85 in picciol tempo gran dottor si feo; 86 tal che si mise a circüir la vigna 87 che tosto imbianca, se ’l vignaio è reo.
query.result:
79 Oh his father truly Felix! 80 oh his mother truly Giovanna, 81 if, interpreted, it holds as is said!
82 Not for the world, for which now he toils 83 behind Ostiense and Taddeo, 84 but for love of the true manna
85 in little time a great doctor he became; 86 so that he set about circling the vineyard 87 that quickly whitens, if the vinedresser is guilty.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
88 E a la sedia che fu già benigna 89 più a’ poveri giusti, non per lei, 90 ma per colui che siede, che traligna,
91 non dispensare o due o tre per sei, 92 non la fortuna di prima vacante, 93 non decimas, quae sunt pauperum Dei,
94 addimandò, ma contro al mondo errante 95 licenza di combatter per lo seme 96 del qual ti fascian ventiquattro piante.
query.result:
88 And to the chair that was already benign 89 more to just poor, not for her, 90 but for the one who sits, who surpasses,
91 not to dispense or two or three for six, 92 not the fortune of the first vacant one, 93 not tenths, which are of the poor of God,
94 he demanded, but against the wandering world 95 license to fight for the seed 96 of which twenty-four plants bind you.

97 Then, with doctrine and with will together, 98 with the apostolic office he moved 99 almost a torrent that high vein presses;
100 and in the heretical thickets he struck 101 his impetus, more vividly there 102 where the resistances were more massive.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 Di lui si fecer poi diversi rivi 104 onde l’orto catolico si riga, 105 sì che i suoi arbuscelli stan più vivi.
query.result: 103 Of him were then made afterwards different streams 104 with which the Catholic garden is furrowed, 105 so that its little shrubs are more alive.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Se tal fu l’una rota de la biga 107 in che la Santa Chiesa si difese 108 e vinse in campo la sua civil briga,
109 ben ti dovrebbe assai esser palese 110 l’eccellenza de l’altra, di cui Tomma 111 dinanzi al mio venir fu sì cortese.
query.result:
106 If such was one wheel of the chariot 107 in which the Holy Church defended itself 108 and won in the field its civil struggle,
109 you should very well understand 110 the excellence of the other, of whom Thomas 111 was so courteous before my coming.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Ma l’orbita che fé la parte somma 113 di sua circunferenza, è derelitta, 114 sì ch’è la muffa dov’ era la gromma.
query.result: 112 But the orbit that made the highest part 113 of its circumference, is abandoned, 114 so that mold is where the thunder was.

115 Its family, which moved straightly 116 with feet to its footsteps, is so turned, 117 that it throws that in front of that behind;
118 and soon will be seen the reaping 119 of the bad cultivation, when the mire 120 will complain that the chest has been taken from it.

121 I say well, whoever searched page by page 122 our volume, would still find paper 123 where he would read “I am he who I used to be”;
124 but it will not be from Casal nor from Acquasparta, 125 from where such come to the writing, 126 one flees it and the other forces it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Io son la vita di Bonaventura 128 da Bagnoregio, che ne’ grandi offici 129 sempre pospuosi la sinistra cura.
query.result: 127 I am the life of Bonaventure 128 from Bagnoregio, who in the great offices 129 always put forth the left care.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Illuminato e Augustin son quici, 131 che fuor de’ primi scalzi poverelli 132 che nel capestro a Dio si fero amici.
query.result: 130 Illuminated and Augustine are here, 131 who were of the first barefoot poor men 132 who made themselves friends with God in the gallows.

133 Hugh of Saint Victor is here with them, 134 and Peter Mangiadore and Peter Spano, 135 who shone below in twelve booklets;
136 Nathan the prophet and the metropolitan 137 Chrysostom and Anselm and that Donatus 138 who deigned to put hand to the first art.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
139 Rabano è qui, e lucemi dallato 140 il calavrese abate Giovacchino 141 di spirito profetico dotato.
query.result: 139 Rabano is here, and shining on the side 140 the Calabrian abbot Joachim 141 endowed with prophetic spirit.

142 To visit so much a paladin 143 moved me the inflamed courtesy 144 of brother Thomas and the discreet Latin;
145 and moved with me this company.
